author: TG_King
body:
If you’re storing your coins on an exchange then you’re doing it wrong. Not your keys not your coins etc.


True a decade isn’t very long. I’ll accept that criticism. I’m just saying that it has done that job well so far.


The point of using Bitcoin is that Bitcoin becomes the middleman of the transaction instead of a bank. There are many benefits to that. No more waiting 3 business days for your money. No more credit card fees or transfer fees. No way for any other entity to intercept your transaction to name a few.


Edit: I missed that you suggested using another cryptocurrency. Currently Bitcoin is the most secure and the most decentralized cryptocurrency. If that changes at some point then sure you could use something else, but that seems fairly unlikely right now.

author: ItsDijital
body:
One of my boys totaled his car on a phone poll driving blackout. He got out and ubered home (lol). Cops came in the morning and asked what the fuck happened. He said he had no idea his car was even "missing".

Same dude, again late night wasted, went to get cigs from 7-eleven. Left his car running out in an empty lot out back. While in there getting cigs, a cop happens to roll up into the empty lot to see whats going on.

As my friend comes around the 7-eleven, he see's the cop standing there over his empty idling car. The cop immediately knows he is wasted and asks him to "turn off his car so they can talk". My friend instead goes "Shit, where did Jason go!? My boy just ran off or something. Sorry officer, but I am way to drunk to get in the driver seat even if it's parked." The cop, shaking his head, then turned off his car and told him he can come get his keys at the station in the morning.

He has at least 7 or 8 near DUI stories, but never a DUI. Thankfully he doesn't drive drunk anymore.

author: redtexture
body:
You may want to explore vertical spreads. 
Example: buy a call at the money, sell a call a few points above the money.  This reduces the cost of an entry, but limits gain, and incorporates a time element into the trade.   

This is a large topic, and hundreds of people have written books and done videos on the topic.

If you already have stock, you could explore selling covered calls above the money on the stock; you can obtain an income; this does limit upward movement gains for the duration of the option, and the stock may be called away (for a gain).

author: YouAreGoingToPrison
body:
I sell secured puts at the money on stock I am looking to buy and sell covered calls maybe 5% out of the money on all stocks in my portfolio.  I try to setup my contracts at the start of the month for expiration at the end of the month but that's not a hard-and-fast rule.  I no longer buy and sell stocks unless they're assigned to me or called away.  I just use options for everything, and all dividends and option premiums are re-invested in developing new positions (no DRIP).

My experiences so far are that people are really impatient, myself included, and I can generate alpha by setting my prices on the contracts I write maybe 20% off the morning's bid/ask.  If it's going the wrong way, I don't chase the trade.  And if the market is illiquid enough I might be able to sell a contract to someone (or some bot) at a nice premium.  Lately I've been a big fan of selling puts in the mid-morning on stocks that are getting hammered (because of an earnings report usually).  My play this week was on CenturyLink and so far that's looking good.

Personally I don't believe in much of the mythology of the stock market, and believe more strongly in the random walk.  For every WSB guy who YOLO's $10K into buying risky calls and reaps massive gains, there's just a pile of people who blow their money because they're impatient or panicked and they are mashing keys without knowing what is going on.  Selling secured puts and covered calls is an awesome way to increase portfolio yield and smooth losses.  I am fine capping my upside.  I'm not expecting Altria or Realty Income to pop 25% after an earnings report, and the options prices reflect that.  So many of the contracts I write expire worthless, and it's just cash in my pocket.

author: ple8DN
body: .. guaranteed scarcity, amongst other things. The math also offers full personal control of its own stored value within the blockchain, without any dependency upon financial intermediaries. It offers undeniable ownership of said value, and no institution can freeze that value, so long as you possess the keys. Speculation is certainly driving the price, but its true value is much more than speculative. The math was designed and engineered to function without a single operator, but with a trustless decentralized network working together for the common goal of flawless functionality— more than any fiat based system could ever hope to accomplish.

author: Zeniant
body:
Market orders remove liquidity and are sometimes subject to higher fees. 

Some limit orders add liquidity and some remove it. Eg a limit order above the “ask” removes liquidity

Market orders are executed almost immediately; a limit order executes when the limit price is met. 

Generally speaking, you should always use limit orders so you’re completely in control of the price you’re buying and selling at. The downside is that sometimes the limit price may not ever be met or it could even be skipped over. 

Slippage is a major concern with market orders. Slippage refers to the sometimes instantaneous change in price from when you send your market orders to when they’re filled. Eg you place a market order of 10 shares @ 25.30 and the share price jumps a bit to 25.33. You thought you were paying $253 for your shares but you paid $253.30 instead (+$0.30 more). Doesn’t seem like a big deal, but let’s say you were buying 100 options contracts at market price $25.30 and get filled at $25.33 instead. 

100x100x$25.33 = $25,300 vs @ $25.30 = $300 straight **lost** down the drain, for no good reason, due to slippage. You could’ve prevented it by setting a limit order to ONLY execute at a price or $25.30 (or **lower**)

As others have said, this is fundamentals 101, and you should do more reading/studying on options. You wouldn’t buy a new computer if you didn’t understand how the debit machine at the micro Centre works (and the sweaty neck beard guy keys in your order incorrectly and overcharges you by $1000).

Edit: if you’re selling that contract sell it at or below bid 

(I previously wrote sell @ midpoint of bid/ask spread which is wrong. I kept thinking “buy” not sell. I am a bull after all)

author: SocalismIsAdisease
body:
>All your points are valid. They will be solved by centralized banks which operate on top of the Bitcoin protocol. Only a few nerds will interact directly with the Bitcoin protocol. (I'd estimate the percentage to be like 3% or something - similar to the percentage of Linux users.)
>
>But here comes the point: It's unlikely that existing banks will be able to adopt. It will be new banks, which will evolve (and already are evolving).

If the decentralized nature of bitcoin is moot, then why even bother switching from traditional banks? What's the benefit from moving from centralized bank that already works to untested centralized bank?

You can't layer the Bitcoin protocol over a bank. It's still hindered by transaction limits, lost keys, hacks, and encryption break by quantum  computing. etc.

Even if block chain proves useful in the future, it's unlikely it will be any of the currently existing one. It would need to be quantum proof at the very least.

author: BigDickAcademy
body:
Not sure how only single asset that is unconfiscateable can be worthless. Does not apply to stocks, cash, RE, gold, precious metals, paintings. Only bitcoin is impossible to confiscate by laws of logic and maths. Seed phrase can't be extracted and duress phrase prevents 5$ wrench attack. This is insane intrinsic value in world where people don't want their assets confiscated + wallets lost over time and people dying means many lost private keys and less Bitcoin in circulation, means -> ever growing price on long term perspective.

You didn't have to be a math genius to figure out this basic logic in 2013 dude.

>  But unless it gains common acceptance, it will be useless

Does not need common acceptance to be useful.

>  Apart from ‘unconfiscatable’, it has no other property that makes it better than paper currency.

What about fact I can carry a million Bitcoin over border under private key in my mind and nobody knows? 

That is enough to warrant high evaluation. And since cash is getting restricted globally anyway, BTC will only grow stronger. If all countries legalised dirty cash and cash restrictions then Bitcoin would suffer, but all countries are constantly moving toward digital money and Bitcoin would ideally replace existing fiat cash for that scenario.

>  Apart from ‘unconfiscatable’, it has no other property that makes it better than paper currency.

Only 1% of world giving shit about BItcoin is way more than enough.

Weird situation:
Had one single NLOK $23put 2/21.
Today the company had some kind of spinoff or special dividend, so now my option is for NLOK1, whereas the stock is still NLOK.

Apparently its still in the money and I’m eligible for an extra cash payout (the option is now worth $2300) but its Robinhood functionality is wonky and I can’t exercise it immediately.

Anyone have this happen before?

body:

How do I exercise this before expiration?  Only option is to sell, but I’m hesitant to do so as the “value” is 0.01

author: imavrik
body: damn! I’m in the same boat as well. I bought 500 shares of NLOK before the ex-div date as well as $24 NLOK protective puts expiring in March. After paying a special dividend of $12 NLOK went to trading at $17 from $26. And my NLOK put option now has the symbol NLOK1 and trades for a penny or two at a 99% loss since purchase. Wtf?! I am trying to find out what right do I have by owning the Put options - that I can exercise at the time of expiry? Also, was there any way I could have known that this would be the likely outcome at the time of purchasing such options? At least E*TRADE didn’t provide any heads up. And even now they are clueless and have asked me to refer to OCC website for additional details on the option.
